SEARCH
Package com.example.atlasevents.data

Class NotificationListener

java.lang.Object
com.example.atlasevents.data.NotificationListener
public class NotificationListener extends Object
Listens for real-time notifications for a specific user and handles their display. Monitors notification preferences, blocked organizers, and incoming notifications, displaying them via toasts (non-blocking) without altering read status.

This class manages three Firestore listeners:

  • Preference listener: Monitors user's notification enabled/disabled preference
  • Blocked organizers listener: Monitors user's list of blocked organizer emails
  • Notification listener: Monitors incoming notifications when preferences allow

Notifications from blocked organizers are silently marked as read without being displayed.

See Also:

  • NotificationHelper
  • FirebaseFirestore

  • Constructor Details

    • NotificationListener

      public NotificationListener(@NonNull android.app.Activity activity, @NonNull String userEmail)
      Constructs a new NotificationListener for the specified user and activity.
      Parameters:
      activity - The Android activity context for displaying notifications
      userEmail - The email address of the user to listen for notifications
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if activity or userEmail is null
      See Also:
      • FirebaseFirestore.getInstance()

  • Method Details

    • start

      public void start()
      Start listening for unread notifications for the current user. Displays each new notification via NotificationHelper and marks it read. Attaches listeners to monitor user preferences, blocked organizers, and incoming notifications. Notifications from blocked organizers are silently marked as read without being displayed. If user email is null, this method does nothing.
      See Also:
      • stop()
      • attachNotificationsListener()
      • detachNotificationsListener()
      • attachPreferencesListener()

    • stop

      public void stop()
      Stops all listeners and cleans up resources. Removes preference, blocked organizers, and notification listeners. Clears the blocked emails cache. Should be called when the activity is stopped or destroyed.
      See Also:
      • start()
